coredata.dc:title: Designing silica-coated CoMn-based catalyst for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis to olefins with low CO2 emission
coredata.dc:creator: Lin, Tiejun
Liu, Peigong
Gong, Kun
An, Yunlei
Yu, Fei
Wang, Xinxing
Zhong, Liangshu
Sun, Yuhan
coredata.dc:description: Co2C nanoprisms exhibit promising catalytic performance for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis to olefins (FTO) but with high CO2 selectivity (>40%). Herein, silica-coated CoMn-based catalyst was designed to limit CO2 production and remained Co2C nanoprisms as active sites unchanged. With a desired coating amount of silica, CO2 selectivity was significantly suppressed to 15.1 C% while enhancing olefins selectivity from 39.7 C% to 58.8 C%, which also shows at least 160 h of stability. It is suggested the silica-coating not only reduces the adsorption capacity of H2O, but also promotes the fast transfer of H2O away from active sites due to the higher adsorption energy of H2O on SiO2 surface, thus suppressing water-gas-shift-reaction (WGSR) activity. Moreover, the sodium promoter can counteract the H2-enrichment effect caused by SiO2-coating and largely restrain CH4 formation and olefins hydrogenation. This work provides an effective strategy to suppress CO2 formation and enhance the carbon efficiency of FTO process.

CO2 selectivity

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Catalytic results. (a) CO conversion and product selectivity (including CO2) for SiO2-coated CoMnAl catalysts. (b) comparison of catalytic activity calculated based on the total molar CO consumption; (c) ASF plots of various samples based on equation: Ln(Wn/n) = nlnα+ ln(1-α)2/α; (d) comparison of products formation rate; (e~f) stability test of CoMnAl@ 6.6Si, reaction conditions: H2/CO= 0.5, 260 °C, 10 bar, 4000 mL g−1 h−1.

Effect of contact time for CoMnAl sample (a) and CoMnAl@ 6.6Si sample (b); (c) Effect of reaction temperature for CoMnAl@ 6.6Si sample at WHSV of 2000 mL g−1 h−1; (d) Effect of H2/CO ratio for CoMnAl@6.6Si sample.
N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms (a), and pore size distribution (b), and FT-IR spectra (c) of various fresh samples.
EDS mapping (a) and linear scan (b) for fresh and spent CoMnAl@6.6Si sample.
Structure characterization. XRD patterns of fresh (a), reduced (b) and spent (c) samples; Raman spectra of reduced (d) and spent (e) samples; XPS spectra of spent samples (f).
(a) The carburization rate of different samples. R denotes the relative CH4 peak area ratio of each sample detected by MS; (b) H2-TPR profile of the catalysts.
(HR)TEM images of spent catalysts with different SiO2-coating contents.
WGSR probe reaction over working CoMnAl (a), CoMnAl@3.4Si (b) and CoMnAl@6.6Si (c) catalyst, and the O/P ratio during WGSR test process (d).
Water vapor sorption isotherms at 25 °C of fresh CoMnAl and CoMnAl@6.6Si catalyst.
Top (above) and side (below) view of optimized configuration and adsorption energy of H2O on stepped-Co2C(020) surface (a) and α-SiO2(001) surface (b).

Transient response curves obtained from propene hydrogenation-pulse experiment at 260 °C over the spent CoMnAl (a), CoMnAl@6.6Si (b), 0.5Na/ CoMnAl@6.6Si (c) and 1.1Na/ CoMnAl@6.6Si (d). R=ratio of C3H6/C3H8 peak area detected by MS.
Catalytic performance over various catalysts for FTO reaction. a .

head.ce:title: Designing silica-coated CoMn-based catalyst for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis to olefins with low CO2 emission

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Co2C nanoprisms exhibit promising catalytic performance for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis to olefins (FTO) but with high CO2 selectivity (>40%). Herein, silica-coated CoMn-based catalyst was designed to limit CO2 production and remained Co2C nanoprisms as active sites unchanged. With a desired coating amount of silica, CO2 selectivity was significantly suppressed to 15.1 C% while enhancing olefins selectivity from 39.7 C% to 58.8 C%, which also shows at least 160 h of stability. It is suggested the silica-coating not only reduces the adsorption capacity of H2O, but also promotes the fast transfer of H2O away from active sites due to the higher adsorption energy of H2O on SiO2 surface, thus suppressing water-gas-shift-reaction (WGSR) activity. Moreover, the sodium promoter can counteract the H2-enrichment effect caused by SiO2-coating and largely restrain CH4 formation and olefins hydrogenation. This work provides an effective strategy to suppress CO2 formation and enhance the carbon efficiency of FTO process.

ce:section.ce:para: Syngas conversion is a key platform for sustainable production of clean fuels and value-added chemicals from various non-petroleum carbon resources including coal, biomass, nature gas, solid waste and CO2 [1–3]. As one of the most important products from syngas conversion, the olefins can be widely applied as key building blocks for the production of plastics and fine chemicals such as polymers, solvents, drugs, cosmetics, and detergents [4,5]. In the last several years, syngas conversion to olefins has attracted great attention from academic and industrial community, and many significant breakthroughs have been made in the product selectivity control for syngas conversion. Olefins with very high selectivity are available over the carbide catalysts [6–9] (FexC, CoxC) or oxide-zeolite bifunctional catalyst systems [10–12]. For example, de Jong and co-workers [6] reported a Na/S modified supported Fe-based catalyst for Fischer-Tropsch to olefins (FTO) with 61% of lower olefins selectivity at a limited CO conversion (<1.0%). Zhong et al. [7] developed Co2C nanoprisms with exposed facet of (101) and (020) that exhibits 60.8% lower olefins selectivity and 5.0% CH4 fraction at 31.8% CO conversion during syngas conversion. Group of Bao [10] and Wang [11] reported oxide-zeolite bifunctional catalysts for syngas conversion to olefins (STO) with ketene or methanol/dimethyl ether (DME) as intermediate, and ~80% of olefins selectivity in hydrocarbons is achieved. However, a large amount of CO2 (cal. 30–50%) is generally co-produced and the reported high olefins selectivity does not take into account the presence of CO2, which would significantly decline when calculated on C-atom basis including CO2. Actually, the production of considerable amount of CO2 is a common problem for carbide- or metal oxide-involved syngas conversion process due to the same catalyst also works as site for water-gas-shift reaction (WGSR) [13–17]. The existence of large amount of CO2 will cause the decrease of catalytic activity and additional energy consumption in unit of heat, compression and separation for industrial process [18,19]. It is still a grand challenge to suppress CO2 formation and improve the carbon efficiency in the field of syngas chemistry.

For syngas conversion to hydrocarbons, the O atom obtained via initial C–O cleavage is removed as H2O and/or CO2 by chemisorbed hydrogenation (H*) and CO*, respectively [20]. The produced H2O may adsorb on the active site and cause WGSR to produce extra CO2. Many attempts are made to suppress the formation of CO2 by tuning the local chemical environment and active site structure. One of the effective strategies is to tailor the surface hydrophobic and hydrophilic properties of catalysts [8,13,21]. For example, Ding and colleagues[8] reported a hydrophobic core-shell FeMn@SiO2 catalyst, and the total selectivity of CO2 and CH4 can be suppressed to less than 22.5% while remaining ~65% of olefins selectivity during FTO reaction. Similar strategies are also reported for Fe-based FTS [21] and Cu-based DME synthesis from syngas [13]. Another approach is to develop newly active structure. Wang et al. [18] prepared a phase-pure ξ- (′)-Fe2C for FTS, and the CO2 selectivity can be suppressed to ~5% at 235 °C. Xie et al. [22] reported a Na/S/Mn modified hcp Co for FTO reaction with 54% of lower olefins selectivity and < 3% of CO2 fraction at 240 °C and 1 bar. Constructing core-shell Zn–Cr @SAPO catalyst [23] or co-feeding CO2 for ZnO-ZrO2/H-ZSM-5 bifunctional catalyst [14] are also applied to limit WGSR activity for syngas conversion. Co2C nanoprisms exhibit promising FTO performance with high olefins selectivity and low methane formation. However, no efficient approach is available to decrease the CO2 selectivity [24].

Herein, we reported a successful design of silica-coated CoMn-based catalyst with limited CO2 emission and Co2C nanoprisms remained as the active sites with high stability. We demonstrated the hydrophilic coating of SiO2 in close proximity with active sites are crucial to inhibit WGSR activity and improve olefins selectivity. The structure-performance relationship was detailed explored by combining experiment design, structure characterization and DFT calculation.

The CoMnAl composite oxides with Co/Mn/Al molar ratio of 3/1/1 were prepared by a co-precipitation method. Typically, Co(NO3)2.6H2O, Mn(NO3)2 and Al(NO3)3.9H2O were dissolved in deionized water to form a mixed salt solution (2 M), and the aqueous solution of Na2CO3 (2 M) were used as precipitant. The precipitation process was performed at 30 °C, pH = 8.0 ± 0.2 with vigorous stirring. After precipitation, the precipitate was aged at 30 °C for 2 h, and then washed with deionized water until the pH reached about 7.0. After drying at 120 °C for 24 h, the obtained precipitate was calcined at 400 °C for 4 h. The CoMn oxide with Co/Mn molar ratio of 1/2 was also prepared with similar procedure.

The SiO2-coated CoMnAl catalyst (CoMnAl@SiO2) was prepared by modified Stöber method [8,21] as following: 20 g of the as-prepared CoMnAl composite oxides powder was dispersed in 400 mL ethanol with a vigorous stirring. Then a certain amount of tetraethoxysilane (TEOS, AR) was added into the above solution. After stirring for 3 h, a mixture solution of ammonia (25–28%, AR) and water with volume ratio of 1:2 was dropped into the above solution and stirred again for 4 h. The resulting solid was centrifuged and washed with ethanol for several times and then dried at 120 °C for 24 h and calcined at 350 °C for 4 h. The sample was finally named as CoMnAl@ xSi, whereas the x denotes the weight content of SiO2. The pure SiO2 was prepared as similar to that of CoMnAl@xSi without adding CoMnAl composite oxides. Similar procedure was also applied for the preparation of CoMn@8.8Si with Co/Mn molar ratio of 1/2 and the residual Na was controlled at 0.83 wt% based on the total weight of the oxides catalyst.

The Na-modified CoMnAl@6.6SiO2 catalyst was prepared by incipient-wetness impregnation with NaNO3 as sodium salt and CoMnAl@6.6Si as precursor. The as-obtained catalyst was dried at 120 °C for 24 h and calcined at 300 °C for 4 h. The γNa/CoMnAl@6.6Si denotes the weight of extra Na was γ wt% based on the total weight of oxides catalyst, which excludes the weight of Na that has already existed in the CoMnAl@6.6Si bulk catalyst.
The element analysis was performed with the X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectroscopy (Rigaku ZSX Primusll, Japan) by SQX calculation.

Nitrogen physisorption experiment was performed to measure the pore structure of catalyst on a Micromeritics 2420 instrument. About 100 mg of sample was degassed at 200 °C under vacuum for 10 h before the test. The specific surface area was calculated using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation. The total pore volume and average pore size were determined by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The adsorption capacity of water vapor of samples was studied by vapor sorption isotherms at 25 °C on a Micromeritics 3flex instrument. The static water contact angle was tested on a Theta Flex instrument.
X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained with a Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray powder diffractometer (40 kV, 40 mA) using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) at a scanning rate of 2 °/min.

The morphology and element composition were characterized by a SUPRRATM 55 scanning electron microscopy (SEM) equipped with an Aztec Energy X-Max 20 energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) detector with an accelerating voltage of 2.0 kV. The transmission electron microscope (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) measurements were performed on a JEOL-JEM 2011 electron microscope with 200 kV accelerating voltage.

The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer with an Al Kα (hv = 1486 eV) radiation source. The binding energy of all spectra was corrected by referring the C 1 s neutral carbon peak at 284.6 eV.

Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiment was carried out using a Micromeritics Autochem-II 2920 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 50 mg fresh sample was loaded into a U-type quartz tube, and purged at 200 °C for 120 min in a 30 mL min−1 He flow. After the temperature was reduced to 50 °C and the baseline kept stable, the gas stream was switched to 5%(v/v) H2/Ar. The temperature was then raised from 50 °C to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1, and the reduction curve was recorded continuously.

Fourier transform infrared spectrum (FTIR) experiment was performed on Nicolet iN10 (Thermo Scientific) infrared spectrophotometer in the range of 400–4000 cm−1. After the background was collected, the spectra of sample were collected with transmission mode.

The cobalt carburization rate was measured with a Micromeritics Autochem-II 2920 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and an MKS Cirrus 2 mass spectrometer [25]. Typically, 50 mg fresh sample was loaded into a U-type quartz tube and then reduced in situ at 400 °C for 180 min, following by exposing 10% (v/v) CO/Ar at 250 °C and 1 bar for 120 min. After that, the gas stream was switched to Ar flow for 30 min to remove gas phase, and then a gas flow of 10% (v/v) H2/Ar was introduced into the tube. The concentration of carbon species was determined by monitoring the effluent for methane (m/z = 16) using an MKS Cirrus 2 mass spectrometer.

Raman spectra of all samples were obtained on a Thermo Scientific DXR 2xi Raman Microscope with an EMCCD detector and a 514 nm Ar ion laser, using a laser power of 4.0 mW, a scanning time of 0.2 s, and 200 scans.

Propylene-pulse experiment was carried out with a Micromeritics Autochem-II 2920 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and an MKS Cirrus 2 mass spectrometer. Typically, 20 mg spent catalyst was loaded into the tube, and the temperature was raised to specified temperature under 30 mL min−1 Ar flow. Then the gas stream was switched to 20 mL min−1 of 10 (v/v)% H2/Ar. 20 mL pure C3H6 was pulsed into the system every 5 min with a sample loop. The effluent for C3H6 (m/z = 42) and C3H8 (m/z = 44) was monitored using an MKS Cirrus 2 mass spectrometer.

The CO/H2O temperature-programmed surface reaction (CO/H2O-TPSR mass) experiment was carried out on a Thermo FTIR spectrometer (Nicolet IS50) with a liquid-nitrogen cooled MCT detector and a TILON LC-D200 M mass spectrometer. Prior to the test, about 20 mg of the spent catalyst was loaded into the cell, and purged with 30 mL min−1 Ar flow for 1 h at 200 °C and then the temperature was reduced to 100 °C. A gas flow of CO (30 mL min−1) with water steam, obtaining by passing through a three-necked round-bottomed flask with a certain amount of deionized water, was introduced the cell, and the temperature was gradually raised from 100 °C to 270 °C. The effluent for CO2 (m/z = 44) was monitored using a TILON LC-D200 M mass spectrometer.

The DFT calculations were performed using Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) with the projector augmented wave (PAW) method and Perdew-Burke-Emzerhof (PBE) semilocal exchange-correlation functional for energy evaluation. The energy cutoff of 450 eV was used and the force acting on each atom less than 0.03 eV/Å was set for convergence criterion of geometry relaxation. Grimme’s DFT-D3 methodology was used to describe the dispersion interactions. The Brillourin zone was sampled with a gamma-centered grid 2 × 2 × 1 through the whole computational process. The energy threshold-defining self-consistency of the electron density was set to 10−6 eV. A 15 Å vacuum space along the z direction was added to avoid the interaction between the two neighboring images. The SiO2(001) surface [26] with 18 at. layers (with the top 10 layers relaxed and the bottom 8 layers fixed) and the Co2C (020) surface [27] with 12 at. layers (with the top 6 layers relaxed and the bottom 6 layers fixed) were used for calculation. The adsorption energy (Eads) of A molecule was defined as Eads = EA/surf - Esurf - EA(g), where EA/surf, Esurf and EA(g) denote the energy of A molecule adsorbed on the surface, the energy of clean surface, and the energy of a free A molecule in gas phase, respectively.

FTO reaction was carried out in a stainless steel fixed-bed reactor. Typically, 0.75 g catalyst of 40–60 meshes mixed with 6.0 g of silica sand was loaded, and then reduced under 200 mL min−1 pure H2 flow at atmospheric pressure at 300 °C for 5 h with a heating rate of 1 °C min−1. Afterward, the reactor was cooled down to 200 °C and pressurized to 10 bar in a flow of syngas (H2/CO=0.5) with WHSV of 4000 mL g−1 h−1. Afterwards, the reaction temperature was raised to 260 °C with a ramping rate of 1 °C min−1 to start the reaction. The reactor effluent gas, after passing through a hot trap (120 °C) and a cold trap (0 °C), was analyzed on-line by an Agilent 7890B gas chromatographer equipped with two detectors. The aqueous products, liquid oil products and solid wax products were collected from cold trap and hot trap, and then analyzed off-line with Shimadzu GC. Detail GC analysis information can be found in our previous work [19]. The catalytic performance after 24 h of stabilization based on gas and liquid compositions were typically used for discussion. The mass balance, carbon balance and oxygen balance were calculated and kept higher than 95%. The repeated experiments carried out under the same reaction condition demonstrated that the studied catalyst shows good reproducibility.

where COinlet and COoutlet represent moles of CO at the inlet and the outlet, respectively, Si denotes the selectivity to product i on a carbon basis, Ni is the molar fraction of product i, and ni is the carbon number of product i.

Table 1 and Fig. 1 present the CO hydrogenation performance of various catalysts with different SiO2-coating amount. For the CoMnAl oxides, a typical Co2C-based FTO performance was observed [7,19], and the CH4 selectivity was as low as 1.7 C% while CO2 selectivity reached 44.7 C% (Table 1, entry 1), closing to the maximum theoretical value of CO2 selectivity (~50%) for syngas conversion [17]. The olefins selectivity was 39.7 C%, which turned into 71.8 C% when being calculated without considering CO2 fraction. Once coating 2.1 wt% of SiO2, CO2 selectivity decreased to 30.8 C% and the olefins fraction increased to 49.1 C%. Further increasing SiO2-coating amount to 6.6 wt% can greatly suppress CO2 selectivity to 15.1 C%, and the olefins selectivity significantly ramped up to 58.8 C%. In other words, the CO2 selectivity decreased by ~66 C%, and olefins fraction increased by ~48 C% when comparing to CoMnAl case. Another intriguing phenomenon is that the catalytic activity was also improved after introducing SiO2, as shown in Figs. 1a and 1b. The CoMnAl@ 6.6Si exhibited activity of 14.6 mmolCO gcat. −1 h−1, which is about 1.3-fold higher than that of CoMnAl. Although the production of CO2 can be further limited by increasing SiO2-coating content, the activity largely decreased along with the decrease of olefins selectivity and increase of paraffins selectivity. For CoMnAl@11.5Si, the CO conversion decreased to 4.9 C% at a higher temperature of 270 °C. Noted that the CH4 selectivity increased moderately with enhancing SiO2-coating amount to 6.6 wt%, and then increased rapidly for the catalyst with a higher SiO2 content, suggesting that the hydrogenation ability was strengthened when introducing large amount of SiO2. Similar conclusion can also be inferred by analyzing the changing trend of hydrocarbons distributions and ratio of olefins to paraffins (Fig. S1). Apparently, the SiO2 coating would weaken the negative deviation degree of C1 product based on the ASF model (Fig. 1c) and shift the products distribution including hydrocarbons and oxygenates to lower carbon direction (Fig. S1). However, the doping of extra Na into SiO2-coated catalyst can markedly suppress hydrogenation ability (Table 1, entry 9 vs entry 3; Fig. S1d vs S1g). For example, the CH4 selectivity decreased from 6.5 C% to 4.3 C% and that of olefins increased to 61.1 C% while CO conversion and CO2 selectivity remained almost unchanged for 0.5Na/ CoMnAl@6.6Si. The O/P ratio increased significantly with the doping of extra Na, and a more notable negative deviation of C1 product was also observed (Fig. 1c).

The product formation rate was further compared and it was found that the desired amount of SiO2-coating indeed can markedly restrain the formation rate of CO2 while simultaneously promote olefins production (Fig. 1d). Similarly, the SiO2-coated CoMn binary oxides also shows significant CO2 inhibiting effect when comparing to previous works [19](Table 1, entry 10).

Since the SiO2 was in-situ deposited on the surface of CoMnAl oxides, another reference catalyst prepared by mortar mixing of CoMnAl oxides and SiO2 powder obtained from hydrolysis of TEOS. As shown in Table 1(entry 8), the as-obtained CoMnAl|6.6Si showed a bit better result than that of CoMnAl, but far worse than CoMnAl@6.6Si in terms of CO2 selectivity and olefins selectivity, which suggests that the space intimacy between CoMnAl oxides and SiO2 plays a profound influence on FTO performance. Obviously, the close contact benefits the suppression of CO2 formation.

The stability test for at least 160 h of time-on-stream demonstrated that CO conversion and products distribution remained almost unchanged for CoMnAl@6.6Si catalyst, while the undesired C1 by products was limited to less than 22 C% (~ 16 C% for CO2 and ~6 C% for CH4) along with high O/P ratio (Fig. 1e,f and Fig. S2).

Moreover, the influence of contact time, reaction temperature and H2/CO ratio for CoMnAl@6.6Si was also investigated, as shown in Fig. 2 and Fig. S3. The contact time is expressed as the ratio of catalyst weight to total flow rate (W/F, s g mL−1). As for CoMnAl, CO conversion increased with contact time, while the CO2 selectivity slightly decreased but kept in the range of 43 ~50 C% (Fig. 2a). The C2–4 olefins selectivity was as high as 63.1 C% at contact time of 0.6 s g mL−1, corresponding to 5.9% CO conversion, and then gradually decreased as increasing contact time. A quite different phenomenon was observed for CoMnAl@ 6.6Si (Fig. 2b). Both CO conversion and CO2 selectivity increased with contact time, but the increment rate of CO2 selectivity was slowed down for contact time more than 1.8 s g mL−1. Under the identic contact time, the CO2 selectivity of CoMnAl@ 6.6Si was always far below the CoMnAl. Increasing reaction temperature enhanced CO conversion and CO2 selectivity (Fig. 2c). The products shifted toward lower components, and the maximum O/P ratio was obtained at 260 °C. Similar changing trend of CO conversion-CO2 selectivity curve was also observed for recent reported modified Fe-based catalysts, which claimed that the CO2 formation can be suppressed under suitable reaction conditions [8,18]. Increasing H2/CO ratio from 0.5 to 2 greatly increased CO conversion to 32.6% while CO2 selectivity remained at around 15.5 C% (Fig. 2d). However, the hydrogenation performance was strengthened to some extent with the increase of H2/CO ratio.

Table 2 and Fig. 3 give the N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms and pore size distribution. All samples exhibited typical type IV isotherms with hysteresis loop, suggesting the existence of mesoporous structure (Fig. 3a). However, the BET surface area and total pore volume decreased with increasing SiO2-coating content due to the deposition of SiO2 on the internal or external surface of pores of CoMnAl oxides, which results in the partial blockage of pore structure. In addition, the observation of slightly increase in the surface area and pore volume of micropores indicated the existence of micropores in SiO2-coating layer [28]. The pore size distribution in Fig. 3b suggested that the mesoporous structure in the range of 3–4 nm gradually disappeared with increasing SiO2 content, leaving the pore size dominated at around 15.5 nm.

FT-IR spectroscopy of fresh samples is showed in Fig. 3c. The peaks at around 3430 and 1630 cm−1 were ascribed to the O-H stretching vibration and H-O-H bending vibration of free and adsorbed water[21,28]. Compared to CoMnAl, the new peaks at 470, 960, 1085 and 1210 cm−1 must originate from the coating of SiO2, in which the peak at 960 cm−1 was attributed to Si-OH stretching vibration and the other three came from the Si–O–Si stretching and bending vibration [21,28]. The gradual increase in Si–O–Si bond intensity demonstrated that the SiO2-coating content increases with increasing TEOS addition content.

EDS mapping and linear scan for various fresh and spent samples are showed in Fig. 4 and Fig. S4~S10. As can be seen, no signal of Si was observed for CoMnAl, while the signal of Co, Mn, Al, Si, Na, and O appeared in all of SiO2-coated CoMnAl catalysts. Mapping results indicated that each element almost distributes uniformly over the catalyst surface, suggesting that most of introduced SiO2 can coat well with the CoMnAl oxides by the modified Stöber method. Especially, the linear scan results further confirmed that the Co and Si element combined together well both in the fresh and spent SiO2-coated CoMnAl catalysts.

The phase structure and chemical state of CoMnAl-based catalysts at different stages were characterized by XRD, Raman and XPS spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. 5a, all of the fresh samples exhibited the similar characteristic peaks at 2θ of 18.9, 31.2, 36.8, 44.8, 55.7, 59.5, 65.3°, corresponding to the Co2Mn1O4.5 phase. No peaks ascribed to aluminate or silicon species could be detected, which may be due to the presence of amorphous form of Si or Al in the samples. After reduction by H2 at 300 °C, the characteristic peaks ascribed to low valency state CoxMn1−xO composite oxides were observed for all of samples (Fig. 5b) [19], and no metallic Co phase appeared, which can further be confirmed by the XPS spectra of reduced samples (Fig. S11). The two Raman spectroscopy peaks of reduced samples between 450 and 700 cm−1 were ascribed to stretching vibration of C–O bond or Mn-O band in CoxMn1−xO (Fig. 5d) [29]. After reaction under syngas, the CoxMn1−xO gradually evolved into Co2C phase, centering at 2θ of 37.0, 41.3, 42.6, 45.7 and 56.6° (Fig. 5c). However, the phase ascribed to CoxMn1−xO was still observed for sample with higher SiO2-coating content, which also shows relative poor crystal structure and lower peak intensity of Co2C. Raman characterization suggested that D-band and G-band dominated the spent samples, indicating the existence of Co2C phase (Fig. 5e) [30]. The intensity of D-band and G-band decreased for sample with SiO2 content larger than 6.6 wt%. XPS spectra of spent catalysts in Fig. 5f confirmed that there is no metallic Co due to the absence of peak at B.E. of 777.9 eV except for the CoMnAl@11.5Si. The above results indicated that the SiO2-coating content has a profound influence on the Co2C formation. To demonstrate this point, we assessed and compared the relative carburization rate by the quantity of methanated carbon under the identic treatment conditions [31]. As shown in Fig. 6a, the CH4 signal peak area decreased with increasing SiO2-coating content, and the peak area ratio of CoMnAl (R1) to CoMnAl@3.4Si (R2), CoMnAl@6.6Si (R3) and CoMnAl@11.5Si (R4) was 5.5/2.6/1.5/1, respectively, demonstrating that the coating of SiO2 can significantly hinder the carburization of Co species.

The reduction behavior of CoMnAl-based catalysts with different contents of SiO2-coating was characterized by H2-TPR. As shown in Fig. 6b, three distinct reduction peaks centered at 226, 352 and 675 °C were identified, respectively, along with a broad reduction band between 400 and 600 °C. The first two peaks are ascribed to a two-step reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ and Co2+ to metallic Co [32], whereas the broad feature may due to the reduction of Co2+ to Co0 in CoxMn1−xO with very small particles [33] or the reduction of MnO2 [28]. The peaks at higher reduction temperature might stem from the reduction of highly disperesd cobalt species that strongly interact with the aluminate support (i.e., CoAl species) [34]. Apparently, the coating of SiO2 slightly changed the reduction profile. The first peak overlapped with the second peak, and the reduction temperature moved toward higher temperature as increasing SiO2 content. A gradual increase in reduction temperature was also observed for the broad band peak, suggesting that the coating of SiO2 would hinder the reduction of Co species because of the possilbe strong metal-support interaction (SMSI). However, the reduction peak of cobalt aluminates to Co0 firstly shifted to higher temperature with increasing SiO2 coating content to 3.4 wt%, and then inversely changed to a relative lower temperature and remained at around 680 °C with further increase of SiO2 content, which may due to the H2-enrichment effect caused by the SiO2-coating layer [28].

Fig. 7 presents the TEM and HRTEM images of spent catalysts. As for spent CoMnAl, a great number of Co2C nanoprisms with specific exposed facet of (101) and (020) were clearly observed, which has already been reported to be the highly efficient active site for FTO reaction and exhibit high olefins selectivity and lower methane selectivity [24]. After coating 3.4 wt% or 6.6 wt% SiO2, Co2C nanoprisms structure was completely preserved. However, the catalyst with higher SiO2-coating content would result in an imperfect Co2C nanoprisms structure with a small amount, confirming that the coating of SiO2 will affect the formation of Co2C nanoprisms.

The Co2C has also been previously demonstrated as the active site for WGSR [15], and the above characterization results suggest that the cobalt phase exists mainly in the form of Co2C. It is necessary to investigate and compare the influence of SiO2-coating on WGSR performance of these SiO2-coated CoMnAl catalysts. Firstly, the reduced catalyst was treated under syngas at 260 °C, 10 bar, WHSV of 4000 mL g−1 h−1. Once the FTO performance became stable, the H2 flow was shut down and the H2O was then pumped into the reactor. As shown in Fig. 8, all catalysts with different SiO2-coating level exhibited a performance similar to that reported in Table 1 under syngas atmosphere, confirming the well repeatability of these catalysts. When the H2 was replaced with H2O, a typical WGSR performance with more than 96 C% CO2 selectivity and less than 1 C% of CH4 fraction was observed for the three studied samples. However, the activity was quite different between each other. The CO conversion of CoMnAl was as high as ~ 65%, while that of CoMnAl@ 3.4Si and CoMnAl@ 6.6Si decreased to ~ 40% and ~ 17%, respectively. The H2/CO ratio in the tail gas further confirmed the observed decreasing WGSR activity, following the order of CoMnAl (1.7) > CoMnAl@ 3.4Si (0.6) > CoMnAl@6.6Si (0.2). The CO/H2O TPSR experiment was also performed to compare the WGSR activity of spent CoMnAl and CoMnAl@ 6.6Si, and the CO2 signal intensity was chosen to reflect the variation of WGSR with temperature. As shown in Fig. S12, the CO2 signal intensity was apparently enhanced at temperature of 150 °C for spent CoMnAl, while that increased until the temperature reached 225 °C for CoMnAl@ 6.6Si. Under the same temperature of 270 °C, a much stronger intensity of CO2 signal was observed for spent CoMnAl. Therefore, it can be reasonably inferred that the SiO2-coating would significantly suppress the WGSR activity, and the suppressing effect was strengthened as increasing SiO2 content.

Another interesting phenomenon that deserves noted is that the very high O/P ratio in the tail gas during WGSR process, and that increased markedly with SiO2 content (Fig. 8d). For example, the O/P ratio of C3 increased from 7.9 for CoMnAl to 11.2 for CoMnAl@3.4Si, and further to 18.1 for CoMnAl@6.6Si. Since the Co2C phase simultaneously works as the active site for FTO and WGSR, the generated H2 via WGSR can react with CO to form hydrocarbons over Co2C site. Additionally, the lower H2/CO ratio corresponds to a higher O/P ratio in the hydrocarbons, in line with the characteristic of Co2C-based FTO [7].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Insight into the role of SiO2-coating on structure-performance relationship
ce:section.ce:para: Combining the insights provided by the above results, the SiO2-coating strategy exhibits profound influence on the catalytic performance of CoMn-based FTO catalyst, especially in terms of suppressing the production of CO2 and enhancing olefins formation rate (Table S1). The Co2C nanoprisms has already been demonstrated as highly efficient active site for FTO reaction, which can readily derive from CoMn spinel structure precursor (i.e., CoxMn1−xO) [24]. XRD characterization confirmed that the coating of SiO2 shows little influence on the precursor structure. The active phase in the spent catalyst was also confirmed as Co2C nanoprisms with exposed facet of (101) and (020). In other words, there is no new active site derived after coating SiO2 on the surface of CoMnAl, and the Co2C still maintained as exclusively active site for FTO. Therefore, it can be speculated that the coating of SiO2 might change the local chemical microenvironment of catalyst surface.

WGSR typical co-exists with FTS reaction over carbide-based catalyst such as FexC or Co2C [17]. Prior report [15] and the above WGSR probe experiment demonstrate that the CO and H2O can react via WGSR over the identic Co2C active site. According to the study of Bukur et al., the maximum possible value of CO2 selectivity during FTS is 50 C% (Scheme S1), and high values of CO2 selectivity would be indicative of high WGSR activity [17]. As for the Co2C-catalyzed CO hydrogenation, the CO2 selectivity remains in the range of 40–50% at a CO conversion of 10–40% (Fig. S13). Similar phenomenon is observed in the work of Liu et al. [35], where they analyzed the relationship between CO conversion and CO2 selectivity from perspective of thermodynamic equilibrium and inferred that the WGSR contributes to the formation of CO2 during syngas to olefins over oxide-zeolite bifunctional catalyst. Therefore, we can speculate that the H2O produced from CO hydrogenation may adsorb on active site and participate in the reaction with CO to produce CO2. It would be an effective strategy to limit WGSR activity and CO2 formation by preventing the readsorption of water and shortening the retention of water on the catalyst surface via surface modification.

In this case, the SiO2 was uniformly deposited on the internal or external surface of CoMnAl oxides, resulting in the decreased BET surface area and total pore volume. The mesoporous in the range of 3–4 nm of the CoMnAl also continuously decreased, which will weaken the capillary effect of water and reduce the adsorption capacity of water on the SiO2-coated catalyst. To verify this point, the water vapor sorption isotherms of CoMnAl and CoMnAl@6.6Si was performed and compared. As shown in Fig. 9, the water vapor adsorption capacity of CoMnAl@6.6Si dramatically decreased compared to CoMnAl, suggesting that the coating of SiO2 can effectively hinder the adsorption of water. Moreover, the DFT calculation confirmed that the adsorption energy of water on Co2C (−1.17 eV, Fig. 10a) is much lower than on the SiO2 surface (−2.60 eV, Fig. 10b). The hydrophilicity of samples was further investigated by the water contact angle experiment (Fig. S14) and the result suggests that the water penetrated into the surface of SiO2-coated sample more readily as the contact angle decreased from 41.83° for CoMnAl to 29.57° for CoMnAl@6.6Si. In other words, the SiO2 shows much better water absorbency, and the formed water more easily transfers from Co2C surface to adjacent SiO2 layer, preventing the water from attaching to the Co2C sites for further WGSR. In addition, the comparative experiment (Table 1, entry 5 VS entry 8) suggests that the close contact between Co2C and SiO2 presents lower WGSR activity and CO2 selectivity. We speculate the closer proximity is more beneficial to the transfer of H2O from Co2C to SiO2 sites, thus achieving the decrease of WGSR activity. Therefore, we can conclude that the SiO2-coated catalyst not only can decrease the water adsorption capacity, but also can effectively facilitate the timely desorption of water from Co2C sites and simultaneously prevent the readsorption of water. It is worth noting that the construction of a hydrophilic shell to prevent water attaching to active sites is also reported in the work of Tan and coworkers, where the CO2 selectivity is limited to some extent during oxide-zeolite-based STO process [23]. Ding et al. indicates that the SiO2-coated FeK/Al2O3 catalyst can reduce the negative impact of water as well as restraining WGSR activity for CO2 hydrogenation [36].

Besides, prior study indicates that the co-feeding of CO2 would decrease the catalytic activity and olefins formation rate [19]. Therefore, the suppression of CO2 is expected to benefit the enhancement of catalytic performance. As observed in this study, the activity and olefins selectivity increase markedly under a suitable SiO2-coating content (i.e., ≤ 6.6 wt%). Increasing hydrophilic SiO2-coting amount can further strengthen the diffusion rate of water from active sites to adjacent SiO2 sites, significantly suppressing WGSR activity and decreasing CO2 selectivity. However, increasing SiO2-coating content simultaneously results in the increase of CH4 selectivity and decrease of O/P ratio and catalytic activity due to the increasing mass transfer resistance of the reactant and products [28,37]. A water-rich environment encapsulating the active sites may also happen and cause the deactivation during FTS. Meanwhile, the crystal structure of Co2C nanoprisms structure would also be affected as increasing SiO2-coating level. In addition, the H2-enrichment effect is commonly observed for space confined-type catalyst such as core-shell structure catalysts [28,38]. The appearance of micropores and mass transfer resistance caused by SiO2-coating as well as the decreased sodium content (Table 2) may facilitate the enrichment of H2 in the internal of SiO2 shell and result in H2-rich local chemical environment [28]. Previous studies have strongly suggested that the alkali metals with basicity properties play a vital role in promoting the formation of Co2C [25,33,39], accelerating the desorption of alkene as well as hindering the secondary hydrogenation of alkene [9,40]. The decreased sodium content would boost the hydrogenation ability of a working catalyst and influence the carburization behavior. To verify this hypothesis, a propene-pulse experiment was specially carried out. As shown in Fig. 11a~b, the signal of propane was both observed on the spent CoMnAl and CoMnAl@ 6.6Si. However, the ratio of propene to propane for CoMnAl (R=53.8) was much higher than that of CoMnAl@6.6Si (R=35.4), demonstrating that the olefins hydrogenation is promoted for SiO2-coated catalyst. However, the doping of extra Na can effectively counteract the H2-enrichment effect according to the experiment in Table 1(Entry 9). The 0.5Na/CoMnAl@6.6Si shows a relative lower CH4 selectivity and higher olefins selectivity as well as O/P ratio than that of CoMnAl@6.6Si. The C3H6-pulse experiment further confirmed that the hydrogenation of olefins can be greatly inhibited by introducing Na, in which the R value increased from 35.4 for CoMnAl@6.6Si to 43.7 for 0.5Na/CoMnAl@6.6Si (Fig. 11c) and to 50.7 for 1.1Na/CoMnAl@6.6Si (Fig. 11d). Furthermore, it is reported that the alkali metal promoter can also enhance surface carbon chemical potential and tune the crystallographic orientation of Co2C to form stabilized-facets of (101) and (020), which explains the experimental observed outstanding long-terms stability test [27,39].

To sum up, surface modification of CoMnAl catalysts with suitable amount of alkali metal (i.e., Na) and hydrophilic SiO2 can effectively limit WGSR activity and reduce CO2 selectivity while maintaining higher O/P ratio and lower hydrogenation ability under optimal reaction conditions. To further obtain a solid Co2C catalyst simultaneously possessing high space-time-yield of olefins and limited C1 by-product selectivity, future studies are still needed to regulate the mass diffusion rates of both reactants and products on the active sites interface by tuning SiO2 coating structure and property (i.e., porosity, pore size, thickness, hydrophilicity/hydrophobicity, SMSI, acid-base property).

In conclusion, SiO2-coated CoMn-based catalyst was successfully prepared and applied for FTO reaction. Coating desired amount of SiO2 on CoMnAl composite oxides can effectively suppress the CO2 selectivity from around 45 C% to 15.1 C% along with the enhancement of olefins selectivity from 39.7 C% to 58.8 C%. The catalytic activity and olefins formation rate were also greatly improved, while CO2 formation rate was restrained. Characterization suggests that SiO2-coating would not change Co2C nanoprisms structure with exposed facet of (101) and (020) as FTO active sites. However, the SiO2-coating can significantly weaken the capillary effect of water and reduce the adsorption capacity of water. Higher adsorption energies of H2O on SiO2 surface than Co2C surface also favors the easily transfer of H2O away from active sites and simultaneously prevents the readsorption of water on Co2C sites for further WGSR. The closer proximity shows more promotional effect on inhibitting WGSR. Although the SiO2-coating caused H2-enrichment effect, the introduction of extra alkali metal can counteract the negative effect to some extent and largely improve the O/P ratio as well as restrain the CH4 formation. This work provides a facile and effective strategy to reduce CO2 emission and increase carbon efficiency for Co2C-based FTO reaction.

Fei Yu: Software, Formal analysis. Xinxing Wang: Investigation, Resources.
